title: Subagents

segments.text: Okay then gang, in this lesson I want to
talk about something called sub aents
which are really cool and they allow you
to basically create a whole team working
on your project where each sub agent can
have a different area of expertise that
can be isolated and configured to work
on certain tasks. For example, we could
make a unit test agent whose expertise
and function would be to really hone in
on writing and running tests. Or we
could make a sub agent who specializes
in security audits. We could make a UX
reviewer who specializes in providing
feedback for new components by viewing
them in a browser, etc. Now, each of
these sub aents all run independently
from each other. They have their own
system prompts, tools they&#39;re allowed to
run, and their own context window. So,
they&#39;re a really good way of isolating
certain workflows and tasks. And what&#39;s
really cool is that Claude Code can
delegate tasks to them when it needs to.
So you can kind of think of claude code
as being maybe a senior developer
working on tasks who then instructs
these sub aents to carry out certain
work. And one of the main benefits of
working this way is that each sub aent
has a specialized expertise which we can
fine-tune to excel in a particular area
through detail system prompts. Also
because each sub aent has their own
isolated context window. It keeps their
context clean and focused leading to I
think better results a lot of the time.
And it also means the main thread stays
cleaner and trimmer if we do this
correctly because we&#39;re delegating tasks
to those sub aents. So it reduces the
context overload in your main session.
So then in this lesson we&#39;re going to
make a sub agent who can use the
playright MCP server to preview and
review the UI UX of new components once
they&#39;ve been made. And the workflow is
going to look something like this. We&#39;re
going to use the custom slash command to
tell Claude Code to make a new UI
component for us. Inside that command,
we&#39;re going to add an instruction
telling it to invoke the UX reviewer sub
aent to review its work after it&#39;s made
code edits. That sub aents going to use
playright to open a browser and look at
the component from a UX perspective.
Then it&#39;s going to provide feedback to
the main thread on clawed code which
will make edits to the component based
on that feedback. If needed, it can ask
the UX reviewer again to review the code
or review the uh component in a browser
and provide more feedback until
eventually everyone&#39;s happy and the
component is finished. So let&#39;s give
this a whirl. So then let&#39;s start by
